author: muesliswap
title: Open analytics standard for DeFi
description: DeFi Apps don't follow a standard on how API endpoints providing application data should be structured. Developers are required to write customs analysis tools or develop Dapp specific connectors.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes, there is a real problem of accessing the information on the liquidity pool of DEXs and lending amount of Lending protocols. This problem is specific to Cardano as the smart contracts are close and it is not possible to query them outside without a specific endpoint that is rarely made available. This is different from Ethereum and other EVM-based blockchains where the solidity smart contact code is viewable and because the majority of DEXs are forks of Uniswap which by default has an endpoint that lets developers query useful information. Creating an API standard and engaging leading DEXs and Lending platforms to adopt this standard would permit developers to access the information of liquidity pools and lending amounts. This would create a familiar environment for developers from EVM blockchains to migrate to Cardano and utilize this functionality. As a developer, I have a project in mind that aggregates the info across DEXs, and having this functionality would certainly help me. The project would scale if major DEXs came on board.
f6_assessments.q1: The team behind the proposal also built Muesliswap, which was one of the DEXs on Cardano. The proposer does not provide information on the individual who would deliver the project, but rather rely on an existing pool of developers who currently maintain muesliswap. I would have preferred if the proposer listed the individual who would work on it to judge their merits to deliver the project. The delivery schedule is split into Research and Development with subtasks within each of these sections. The budget is set at just under $8k which is competitive for this type of deliverable at an hourly rate of around $70/h. The team is not planning to come back for additional funding to Catalyst and any overruns will be funded by the muesliswap team. The funding is quite small for this undertaking, but the proposal makes clear that they will deliver an API for their own DEX and design the spec of the API for others to implement and outreach to other protocols. They plan to complete the work in just over a month which I think given their experience with DeFi is realistic. I would expect the embedding of the API standard with other DEXs to take a little longer and allowing more time for integrations would be more realistic. The technology used to implement the solution is not discussed (e.g. will the API be RETS, os Websocket, and will it run on Node, or other) and it would be nice to see this. Also, there is no detail on how the API will read data from the smart contract, it would be good to know if a new smart contract needs to be launched, and if not how will the data be exposed. The proposer considers that there are no material risks because the technology is well understood. I would hover consider that there are risks that the API would not be adopted by the competing platforms and having a standard of an API running only on one DEX is not very useful, so would have liked some detail on how the team would plan to overcome the risk of low adoption.
f6_assessments.q2: Yes, a roadman with the deliverable is provided for the technical part of the proposal. I would however consider that the outreach portion is lacking in detail. The team is committed to being transparent throughout and publishing their API standard. The information on KPI is missing, however, given the project’s short nature, just over 1 month, there would not be much time to review any intermediate KPIs. The success is stated as delivering the API standard document and having it implemented in Muesliswap. I would have liked there to have been a mention of the success metric based on the number of users of the API and adoption by other DEXs. I think it will be possible to audit the project give the objective deliverable, however I feel the metrics fall short of validating the return on intention of making the API useful to a broad range of developers unless there is wider adoption by other DEXs

f6_assessments.q0:
The MuesliSwap team aims to create an open standard and the accompanying tooling required in the hopes that all DEXs on Cardano provide data endpoints to developers in a standardised way.

This would represent a step in the right direction as it could make it easier for developers looking to compile and use data from multiple DEXs in their workflows. As such this initiative is a very good fit for the Developer Ecosystem challenge on multiple fronts as it not only seeks to create a standard but also the necessary tooling for its implementation.

Given that MuesliSwap is already an established player in the space they have a very good chance at actually convincing the other major DEXs on Cardano to adhere to the standard that they are developing. This is crucial, as there’s little point in developing a standard that no one adopts.
f6_assessments.q1:
The implementation plan is adequately presented and paints the picture of a straightforward project without too many complications or dependencies. 1 week is allocated to research and communication with other players in the DeFi space and 1 month is the length of time estimated for developing the API.

The budget matches these estimations and is reasonably calculated at a total of 85 hours. It’s my assessment that this estimation is very conservative and there is a very high likelihood that the team will actually end up spending a lot more than 15 hours on the initial stage of the project, especially if they plan to contact and coordinate with all the other major players in the Cardano DeFi space. However, the team has indicated that if the project goes over budget any extra costs will be covered by them.

The fact that the proposal comes from the developers of one of the major DeFi dApps on our blockchain does a lot to bolster the image of the team and their competence. This is especially important as unfortunately, the team does not provide any information about the exact people that will be working on this project, their credentials or any links to professional profiles (LinkedIn) or examples of previous work that could otherwise demonstrate their competence and inspire trust in their ability to deliver the project if funded. However, I do recommend that in the future the team includes such information as not all PAs or voters may be aware of their past accomplishments. The Cardano community is growing daily.

The MuesliSwap team has not been funded by Catalyst previously, Fund 9 being the first time they have submitted proposals. They have submitted 9 proposals.
Source: https://www.lidonation.com/en/project-catalyst/users/2032 

Given this, I really would have liked to see a description of how they plan to manage the workload if all projects are funded.  Especially because this is now a requirement of the newly introduced workload questions in Fund 9. They did answer “Yes” to the question of other Fund 9 proposals but unfortunately failed to provide additional details in the Feasibility section as requested in the question description on the submission form. The proposal does say that they are a team of 9 people, so I’m not suggesting that they won’t be able to manage the workload if all proposals are funded but it would have been helpful to voters to have a clear plan of how they plan to manage that situation in case it comes to pass. This is why I strongly recommend that they do include such a plan in the future.  As this was a new requirement that unfortunately very few proposals actually met I will not be lowering my Feasibility score for this omission at this time.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal is very clear on what it plans to deliver and the timeframe it plans to deliver it in, there is very little ambiguity which will help a lot when community members conduct audits on the deliverables of this project. Having said that I do wish that the MuesliSwap team would have clearly indicated what communication channels can the Cardano community use to stay up to date with the progress on the project and where they plan to publish and make the results of their work public, be it GitHub or any other relevant platform.

The definition of success is in-line with the goals of the project and as they state, the results of this proposal are guaranteed to be adopted by at least one major DeFi platform in the Cardano space, theirs. Though I sincerely hope that this won't be the outcome, and what they are developing will indeed become the standard for the whole space going forward.

My assessment of this proposal in the Developer Ecosystem challenge is based on my experience as a project manager working directly with Cardano developers since July 2021. I have participated in almost all roles in Project Catalyst since February 2021, including as a previously funded proposer, and I’ve been involved with the Cardano development community and NFT community for about a year and a half.

f6_assessments.q0: The author has identified a critical problem with the current API protocol on DeFi applications: DeFi applications do not follow any standard on how API endpoints should provide data. This proposal addresses the challenge by creating a standard for DeFi dApps API. This project could unify the data communication across dApps using DeFi protocols if carried out successfully. This standard benefits Cardano developers, building a new application on top of existing DeFi applications by creating an open, shared convention on how data should be sent and read. This project would then be implemented by MuesliSwap, the team that would be working on the project itself. It would ensure that this project is implemented on one of the most significant DeFi protocol in the Cardano ecosystem. However, for the standard to be massively adopted, it needs a way to be recognized and published. This proposal still lacks that. To further improve this proposal, the author could specify how the standard would be published and receive continuous feedback from the community.
f6_assessments.q1: The team working on this proposal are the same people building one of the most significant DeFi protocol on the Cardano Ecosystem, MuesliSwap. This team consists of nine people with experience in different fields. This fact gives the team significant leverage for the feasibility of this project. They are also the right people for the job as they deal practically with this problem. The team behind the proposal, in this case, MuesliSwap, also stated that it would adopt the proposed standard. This fact gives the team more incentive to carry out this project successfully. It is also stated that every budget deficit will be the team’s liability; this eliminates any budget-related risks. Moreover, the author said that the team already has a general idea of how the API endpoints could be standardized. The team plans to finish this project in a month and a week. The timeline planning is well laid-out and very informative. The budget breakdown is also very clear and reasonable—the author breakdown the budget planning hourly. In conclusion, this proposal is feasible and is highly likely to be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The audit process of this proposal will be delivered on documentation. That is how far as auditability on this proposal goes. The success measure of this project is to “enrich the entire ecosystem” by developing an API standard. However, the author has not provided any quantifiable measure of that goal. An example of quantifiable measurement of that statement would be “how many projects successfully implement this standard?” or “how much positive feedback was received for implementing this standard?”. Or, the author could use metrics such as the number of people who visited the standard page, or if the standard is hosted on GitHub: how many activities could be seen on the GitHub page? This quantifiable measure could be presented in the progress report, critically enhancing the auditability of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Unifying and standardizing API calls for project that make use of DEXs' data and queries is a very suitable direction for this challenge setting. The tooling to enable decentralized finance will become very useful in most if not all dApp implementations using tokens and some form of monetary value, so this can potentially cater a very broad range of projects and developers. The spirit of open source employed by OpenSwap Technologies and their willingness to share their research with other Cardano projects increase the impact this may have on the entire ecosystem. Deployment, testing and motitoring frameworks are likely to benefit. Open source contributions specifically for Haskell and Plutus are always welcome, but especially so if they have an immediate real world applicability. A project that stands out for its high alignment with the challenge brief, clear goals and modest budget.
f6_assessments.q1: The MuesliSwap team are of course well-known and have a working, popular DEX, Github repos and other proposals that showcase their technical prowess. This is a relatively small proposal with a very modest budget and limited scope, and the budget breakdown and timeline are reflecting that. Sufficient information has been provided to back up the claims the proposers make, and the team and business plan make me confident that a DeFi standard can be created successfully. It is reassuring to see that the team will consult with other DeFi teams as part of this project, and access to the entire team at MuesliSwap (9-strong) will be very useful for the development of the API endpoint analysis, improvement and standard. It is extremly generous and reassuring that MuesliSwap will cover any potential budget overrun, and it is therefore almost inconceivable that this project cannot be finished as a complete success.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposers promise to be transparent and publish their findings along the way as open source. A little more could have been done to make this credible and provide links or goals inside the section as a convenience to auditors and gesture of transparency to assessors and voters. I "assume" that the information "will" be sufficient to audit and follow the progress, but would have loved to be sure. I am nit-picking here, but as I like this proposal a lot and have ranked it highly overall, I would like to stress that auditability to responsibility towards the Ada holders and voters are not optional features of the proposal submission form :-)

solution: We develop a common API standard that will make it easier for information aggregators to include Cardano DeFi protocols and ensure that all protocols deliver the necessary information.
experience: We are OpenSwap Technologies - the team behind MuesliSwap, one of the biggest decentralized apps on Cardano. As developers of DeFi infrastructure, we have experience with all relevant aspects of Cardano (off-chain, on-chain code), Haskell programming and smart contract audits.
